about: Basketball is a team sport played between two teams of five players each. The objective is to score points by shooting a ball through the opponent's hoop.

2.1 - Court
Basketball is played on a rectangular court with specific dimensions. It features a hoop at each end.
2.2 - Ball
The game uses a spherical ball made of leather or synthetic material.
A standard basketball team consists of five players on the court at any given time. Substitutions are allowed during stoppages in play.
Players are typically assigned positions such as point guard, shooting guard, small forward, power forward, and center, each with specific responsibilities on the court.

5.1 - Scoring
Points are scored by successfully shooting the ball through the opponent's hoop.
5.2 - Dribbling
Players must dribble (continuously bounce) the ball while moving.
5.3 - Passing
Passing the ball to teammates is a crucial aspect of gameplay.

6.1 - Traveling
Moving without dribbling the ball is a violation.
6.2 - Double Dribble
Stopping and then restarting dribbling is a violation.
6.3 - Personal Fouls
Physical contact beyond the rules is considered a foul.
Free throws are awarded after certain fouls and are taken from the free-throw line. They are uncontested shots at the hoop.
Shots made from beyond the three-point line are worth three points instead of the usual two.
A shot clock limits the time a team has to attempt a shot. If the shot is not taken in time, the opposing team gains possession.
Securing possession of the ball after a missed shot is crucial for maintaining offensive opportunities.
Defensive players aim to prevent the offensive team from scoring by blocking shots, stealing the ball, and forcing turnovers.
Coaches can call timeouts to provide instructions to their team or to give players a rest during the game.
If the score is tied at the end of regular play, overtime periods are played to determine the winner.
Coaches can make substitutions during stoppages in play to replace players on the court.
